lessons.title: What Brakes Do
lessons.text: Brakes slow down or stop a moving vehicle. They work by creating friction that resists motion. When you press the brake pedal, you are telling the car to turn motion into heat.
lessons.analogy: Brakes are like putting your hand on a spinning wheel. The rubbing slows it down.

quiz.question: What do brakes do?
quiz.feedback: Correct. Brakes slow down or stop motion.

lessons.title: The Brake Pedal
lessons.text: The brake pedal is the driverâ€™s control for the braking system. When you press the pedal, it sends force into the brake system so braking can begin.
lessons.analogy: The pedal is like the handle on a clamp. Your foot pressure controls how tight the clamp squeezes.

quiz.question: What does pressing the brake pedal do?
options: Sends force into the brake system
quiz.feedback: Yes. Pressing the pedal sends force into the brake system.

lessons.title: Hydraulic Brake System
lessons.text: Most cars use a hydraulic brake system. This means brake fluid carries force from the pedal to the wheels. Fluid does not compress easily, so force moves evenly through the system.
lessons.analogy: Like pushing on one end of a filled water hose and seeing pressure move to the other end.

quiz.question: Why is brake fluid useful?
quiz.feedback: Correct. Brake fluid transfers force evenly through the system.

lessons.title: Master Cylinder
lessons.text: The master cylinder turns pedal movement into hydraulic pressure. It pushes brake fluid through the brake lines when the pedal is pressed.
lessons.analogy: The master cylinder is like a syringe pushing liquid through a tube.

quiz.question: What does the master cylinder create?
quiz.feedback: Right. The master cylinder creates hydraulic pressure.

lessons.title: Brake Lines
lessons.text: Brake lines carry pressurized brake fluid from the master cylinder to each wheel. They must be strong and sealed so fluid cannot leak.
lessons.analogy: Like strong pipes carrying water under pressure.

quiz.question: What do brake lines carry?
quiz.feedback: Correct. Brake lines carry brake fluid.

lessons.title: Disc Brakes
lessons.text: Disc brakes use brake pads to squeeze a spinning metal disc called a rotor. The friction between the pads and rotor slows the wheel.
lessons.analogy: Like squeezing a spinning plate between two blocks of wood.

quiz.question: What do brake pads squeeze?
quiz.feedback: Yes. Brake pads squeeze the rotor.

lessons.title: Drum Brakes
lessons.text: Drum brakes use curved shoes that press outward against the inside of a drum. Some cars use drum brakes on the rear wheels.
lessons.analogy: Like pushing outward against the inside of a spinning bucket.

quiz.question: Where do drum brake shoes press?
options: On the outside of a disc
Against the inside of a drum
quiz.feedback: Correct. Drum brake shoes press outward against the inside of a drum.

lessons.title: Parking Brake
lessons.text: The parking brake holds the vehicle in place when parked. It usually works through cables rather than hydraulic pressure.
lessons.analogy: Like setting a mechanical lock instead of holding pressure.

quiz.question: What is the main job of the parking brake?
quiz.feedback: Correct. The parking brake holds the car when parked.

lessons.title: Brake System Review
lessons.text: Say these parts out loud in order and explain each in one sentence: brake pedal, master cylinder, brake lines, brakes at the wheels. If you can say it clearly, you understand it.
lessons.analogy: This is your slow walk through how stopping power moves from your foot to the road.
